results.title: ‘Kimberly Akimbo’ Will End Its Broadway Run in April
results.abstract: The Tony winner for best musical, about a high school girl with a rare genetic disorder and a criminally dysfunctional family, will begin a national tour in September.

multimedia.caption: “Kimberly Akimbo,” which stars Victoria Clark and features Justin Cooley, won five prizes at last year’s Tony Awards, the most of any production.

results.title: In a Land of Primary Colors, Home Is Where the Bounce House Is
results.abstract: As part of Under the Radar, Nile Harris resurrects his play that weaves together text, sound, minstrelsy and dance to explore the American experience.
des_facet: This House Is Not a Home (Play)

multimedia.caption: Nile Harris on the set of “This House Is Not a Home.” But it is a bounce castle. Harris said a bounce house can represent any institution — and then morph back into “a preadolescent meme.”
multimedia.copyright: Elias Williams for The New York Times

results.title: And the 2023 Oscar Nominees Should Be …
results.abstract: Academy voters will do what they want, but if our chief critics had their way, these are the films and performers that would be up for Oscars this year.
results.byline: By Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson

results.title: Taraji P. Henson Is Tired of Fighting
results.abstract: The “Color Purple” star talks candidly about her battles to get cast and paid her worth. Even as an Oscar-nominated veteran, she had to audition for her new film.

multimedia.caption: Taraji P. Henson said that it seemed like whenever salary discussions for a new job come up, “I’m right back like I did nothing. I almost had to walk away from ‘Color Purple.’”
multimedia.copyright: Erik Carter for The New York Times

results.title: A Reinvented ‘True Detective’ Plays It Cool
results.abstract: Starring Jodie Foster and Kali Reis, the new season travels to Alaska and takes on a decidedly more female perspective, starting with a new showrunner.

results.title: As the Art World Watches, an Oligarch Takes an Auction House to Court
results.abstract: At trial next week, Dmitry Rybolovlev is set to accuse Sotheby’s of helping an art dealer trick him into wildly overspending for works, a claim the company disputes.
results.byline: By Graham Bowley and William K. Rashbaum

multimedia.caption: Dmitry Rybolovlev, a Russian billionaire who owns Monaco’s soccer team, is accusing Sotheby’s of helping a man who he says cheated him in the purchases of master works of art.
multimedia.copyright: Benjamin Bechet for The New York Times

results.title: ‘Reacher’: Women Want What He’s Got, and Not Just the Beefcake
results.abstract: The hit Amazon series about a bone-crushing crime fighter isn’t only Dad TV. Women dream of having the character’s freedom and abilities, too.

multimedia.caption: The title character of “Reacher,” played by Alan Ritchson, doesn’t start too many fights, but he does finish them. You don’t have to be a dad, or a man, to envy that.

results.title: Former Mr. Bungle Saxophonist Charged With Murder in Girlfriend’s Death
results.abstract: Theobald Lengyel, a saxophonist, helped form the experimental rock band in Northern California in the mid-1980s. His girlfriend had been missing since early December.

results.title: David Soul, a Star of the Hit Cop Show ‘Starsky & Hutch,’ Dies at 80
results.abstract: An actor and singer, he rose to fame in the 1970s as one half of popular television crime-fighting duo. He also notched a No. 1 hit single in the U.S.

multimedia.caption: David Soul on the set of “Starsky & Hutch” in 1976, the year he released his debut album as a pop singer. He had No. 1 hit the next year with “Don’t Give Up on Us.”

results.title: Richard Gaddes, Opera Impresario Who Spotted Young Talent, Dies at 81
results.abstract: As leader of opera companies in Santa Fe and St. Louis, he welcomed new works as well as new artists.

results.title: Vinie Burrows, Acclaimed Actress Who Became an Activist, Dies at 99
results.abstract: She got her start on Broadway at 15. But after finding a dearth of roles for Black women, she ultimately turned to one-woman shows that addressed racism and sexism.

multimedia.caption: The actress Vinie Burrows in 2019. She worked into her 90s and won an Obie lifetime achievement award in 2020.

results.abstract: This week we introduce a new format for Galleries with one critic at the helm, searching out new artists and some of the most notable exhibitions. results.title: Martha Diamond, Painter Who Captured New York Vistas, Dies at 79
results.abstract: Her work, at the border of representation and abstraction, influenced younger painters but did not gain broad public recognition until late in life.

multimedia.caption: Martha Diamond in her New York studio in 1993. She often painted the view from her loft on the Bowery, where she lived and worked since 1969.

results.title: Happy Puppies and Silly Geese: Pushing the Limits of A.I. Absurdity
results.abstract: A recent update to ChatGPT made it easier to create images. It wasn’t long before some began pushing the chatbot to its limits.

results.title: Luna Luna: A Fantasy That Comes With a Price Tag
results.abstract: A blockbuster restaging of an “art amusement park” from 1987 aims to recover a lost element in art — fun. But in our age of hype and commerce, was it doomed to fall short?

multimedia.caption: Three visitors in front of Jean-Michel Basquiat’s white Ferris wheel at Luna Luna, the art amusement park restored in Los Angeles. His black glyphs adorning each gondola symbolize some aspect of chaos or Americana or slapstick.
multimedia.copyright: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
